weeklyTopNews.title: Melburnians urged to wear masks as Victoria records 288 new coronavirus cases
weeklyTopNews.summary: Victorians have been urged to wear masks when they leave their homes after the state recorded 288 COVID-19 cases in 24 hours, the largest daily increase of the pandemic so far. Premier Daniel Andrews said masks were not being made mandatory, but people in lockdown areas should wear masks in situations where they cannot maintain physical distancing. He said the Government would order 2 million reusable masks for community distribution, and boost local manufacturing capabilities.

weeklyTopNews.title: Victorian Government announces $534 million support package for businesses hit by coronavirus lockdown
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Victorian Government has announced a $534 million support package for businesses impacted by the coronavirus lockdown. The package includes: a $30 million fund for hospitality businesses; a $26 million mental health support package for small business; a $40 million fund to help regional tourism businesses to cover refunds and marketing; $20 million for small businesses in Melbourne's CBD; and $5,000 grants to be made available for 80,000 eligible businesses in metropolitan Melbourne and the Mitchell Shire. Treasurer Tim Pallas said the state's unemployment rate could peak at 11 per cent and gross state product could decline by about 14 per cent relative to pre-pandemic forecasts.

weeklyTopNews.title: Record calls to mental health services during second lockdown
weeklyTopNews.summary: Victorians are reaching out to mental health services for support in record numbers as Melbourne enters a second coronavirus lockdown. Lifeline is reporting a 22 per cent surge in calls in Victoria since Sunday compared with the same time last year, while calls from Victoria to Beyond Blue’s support services have doubled in the past fortnight. Lifeline Australia chairman John Brogden said the service had received almost 90,000 calls a month since March, which amounted to a call every 30 seconds. This was a sign the strict lockdown measures were taking a toll on the mental health of Victorians, he said.

weeklyTopNews.title: Coronavirus crisis: WA Premier Mark McGowan announces phase five start pushed back from July 18 to August 1
weeklyTopNews.summary: Mark McGowan says WA’s hard border with the rest of the nation will be up for “as long as it takes” amid news phase five of WA’s COVID-19 restrictions will be delayed until August 1. The Premier said border measures between WA and Victoria could be tightened even further yet and WA Police Commissioner Chris Dawson flagged stopping all planes from Victoria from coming into WA as being an option to keep COVID-19 out of the state. It comes amid news from the Premier that the start of WA’s next phase of restrictions had been pushed back two weeks. The Premier said WA had decided to be extra cautious in delaying restriction relaxations because of the situation in Victoria.

weeklyTopNews.title: Restrictions to ease in eight of Melbourne's locked-down public housing towers
weeklyTopNews.summary: A hard lockdown is set to end for eight of the public housing estates in Melbourne on Saturday, meaning people will be able to leave for essential purposes. All towers, except the 33 Alfred Street estate, will move to Stage 3 restrictions, in line with the rest of metropolitan Melbourne. This means residents will be able to leave for essential work, study, exercise or care responsibilities. Tenants in the Alfred Street building, where there have been 53 cases of COVID-19, will have to remain inside for another nine days. However, they will be allowed to have supervised exercise outside.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW-Victoria border control to be in place for at least six weeks as Queensland and SA clamp down
weeklyTopNews.summary: Border controls between Victoria and New South Wales will remain in place for at least six weeks, while Queensland will turn Victorians away at the border and South Australia will require those permitted into the state to wear face masks. Meanwhile, Tasmania has extended its state of emergency until 31 August, in response to the Melbourne outbreak, but will consider reopening its borders to other states.

weeklyTopNews.title: Josh Frydenberg says Coalition will extend income support and may bring forward tax cuts
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Morrison government is considering bringing forward income tax cuts and will extend income support beyond September, the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, has said. Frydenberg and the prime minister, Scott Morrison, have been increasingly frank about the need for the extension of economic supports as Victoria re-enters a six-week lockdown to fight the spread of Covid-19. Although the income tax cut proposal is yet to go to cabinet and the government’s decision on extending the $70bn jobkeeper program will not be announced until 23 July, Victorian businesses are requesting an extra two months of wage subsidies citing the new lockdown. It comes as banks have announced they will extend the six-month suspension of loan repayments by a further four months for business loan and mortgage customers who are still experiencing financial hardship.

weeklyTopNews.title: NSW-Victoria coronavirus breach after Melbourne Jetstar flight lands in Sydney where passengers aren't screened for COVID-19
weeklyTopNews.summary: Passengers on a flight from Melbourne to Sydney last night disembarked without being screened by NSW Health officials, in a major breach of the state's coronavirus protocols. An email from Sydney Airport leaked to the ABC claims Jetstar breached NSW Government health orders by allowing travellers on flight JQ520, which landed at 6:53pm, to get off without being checked. Federal Health Minister Greg Hunt said his department would seek answers from the Victorian and New South Wales governments.

weeklyTopNews.title: Australia set to cap international flights to contain spike in coronavirus cases
weeklyTopNews.summary: Australia will reduce the number of international flights entering the country to ease pressure on hotel quarantine amid Melbourne's coronavirus outbreak. Prime Minister Scott Morrison will unveil a plan to cut the number of international flights at Friday's national cabinet meeting with state premiers. "In Victoria, we have suspended those flights coming in and that has meant that people have moved on to other flights going into other capitals,"he told reporters in Canberra on Wednesday.

weeklyTopNews.title: Metropolitan Melbourne put into six-week lockdown after surge of 191 new coronavirus infections
weeklyTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews says metropolitan Melbourne will be put into a six-week lockdown after recording 191 new coronavirus infections on Tuesday. The lockdown, which will also apply to the Mitchell Shire north of the city, will take effect from 11.59pm on Wednesday. Mr Andrews told reporters on Tuesday new infections would quickly spiral out of control if drastic suppression measures weren't put in place.

weeklyTopNews.title: Queensland joins WA in push for international flight cap amid Melbourne virus spike
weeklyTopNews.summary: Queensland and Western Australia have urged the federal government to cap international flights arriving in Australia to ease pressure on hotel quarantine. State premiers have raised concerns with Prime Minister Scott Morrison as Victoria struggles with a concerning coronavirus infection spike. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said extreme caution should be applied when dealing with arrivals from overseas. WA Premier Mark McGowan wants a cap of about one international flight every three days landing in Perth.

weeklyTopNews.title: Victoria-NSW border to close for the first time in 100 years as Melbourne coronavirus cases hit record daily high
weeklyTopNews.summary: The border between New South Wales and Victoria will close at 11:59 on Tuesday night as coronavirus cases continue to surge in Victoria. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirmed the decision on Monday morning as the state recorded another 127 coronavirus cases overnight, a record daily increase for the state. The border closure decision was made in consultation with Prime Minister Scott Morrison and NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian, Mr Andrews said. The decision marks the first time the Victoria-NSW border has been shut in 100 years - officials last blocked movement between the two states in 1919 during the Spanish flu pandemic.

weeklyTopNews.title: WA pushes for cap on international flights to reduce coronavirus risk
weeklyTopNews.summary: WA Premier Mark McGowan has sought Commonwealth approval to cap the number of international flights landing in Perth. Mr McGowan said he had requested international arrivals be limited to "something in the vicinity of one flight per three days". He said WA continued to lead the country as a "safe haven" from COVID-19, and the state had not recorded a case of community infection since April 11. Mr McGowan said there had recently been an uptick in domestic and international arrivals at Perth Airport. He said Cabinet had today approved the drafting of legislation to force any returning travellers to pay for a compulsory 14 days of quarantine.

weeklyTopNews.title: 'Play it safe': AMA calls for a nationwide freeze on lifting COVID restrictions
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Australian Medical Association's President, Tony Bartone has urged states to temporarily cease the lifting of restrictions. This is in response to 108 new cases in Victoria on Saturday. Dr Bartone said it was disappointing that the problem's in Melbourne's hotspots were linked to failures to follow "established and successful" public health guidelines.

weeklyTopNews.title: A group of 3,000 Melburnians have been locked down in public housing towers. But how will authorities manage it?
weeklyTopNews.summary: Authorities have placed over 3000 residents across nine public housing towers in lockdown. Premier Daniel Andrews has urged residents to to view these measures as protective rather than as a punishment. Many Victorians have rallied behind the affected residents, including a crowdfunding campaign for residents, organised by the Victorian Trades Hall Council, that has raised over $250,000 so far.

weeklyTopNews.title: Cap on international arrivals introduced at Sydney Airport to ease coronavirus quarantine demands
weeklyTopNews.summary: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has warned that international flights to Sydney over the coming weeks will be subject to a cap on arrivals and flights could be cancelled. At the request of the NSW Government, new Federal Government limits will be introduced from midnight tonight. NSW Health said overseas arrivals will be capped at 450 passengers a day, with a maximum of 50 passengers allowed per incoming flight. The move is aimed at easing pressure on hotel quarantine capacity.

weeklyTopNews.title: More suburbs in lockdown as Victoria records 108 new coronavirus cases
weeklyTopNews.summary: More suburbs in Melbourne's inner-north will be placed in lockdown and thousands of residents in nine public housing towers will be confined to their homes after Victoria recorded 108 new coronavirus cases. The suburbs of Kensington, Flemington and North Melbourne, in postcodes 3031 and 3051, will join 36 others where stage three coronavirus restrictions apply, meaning residents can only leave their homes for four reasons: food or essential supplies; medical care or care giving; exercise; or for work or education. The lockdown will take effect from 11.59pm on Saturday. A large coronavirus cluster has emerged in the Flemington and North Melbourne public housing estates where residents will be placed in a "hard lockdown" for at least five days, "effective immediately".

weeklyTopNews.title: More than 10,000 Victorians refused coronavirus tests
weeklyTopNews.summary: More than 10,000 people have refused to be tested for coronavirus in Melbourne's hotspot suburbs as 66 new cases across the state were confirmed. Health Minister Jenny Mikakos labelled the refusal as "disappointing" and urged residents to get tested as she speculated the mass coronavirus outbreak in Victoria could be linked to a "super spreader". "There seems to be a single source of infection for many of the cases that have gone across the northern and western suburbs of Melbourne," Ms Mikakos said. The health minister said the government is investigating the reasons behind the mass refusal of testing, but reassured the community that 24,000 tests had been undertaken yesterday.
